item.title: Gesture Drawing over the Weekend
item.description:
A gesture practice ranging between 2 to 5 minutes per drawing.

I sketched in Krita and used its new build in recorder to create a timelapse of the drawings. See the gallery below the video for individual images.

item.title: Ultra Short: Morning Sortie
item.description:
It always strikes me how gracefully gliders are lifted into the sky and seeing them fly on the currents above is like looking at an aquarium. I wanted to capture a snippet of that observation in this short animation.

Editing beforehand

I started by drawing thumbnails of the images in my head and edited those until I was left with somewhat of a general idea and flow. I then transferred the edited thumbnails to a storyboard:

This storyboard was also trimmed down. Shots of the winch pulling the plane were unsuitable for the mood I was aiming for. There was a probability of it becoming too much like the real thing, making it quite bland and predictable. I also decided to reveal the plane only until the very last end, so as to maintain a slight mystery.

Animating inanimate objects

The things to be animated were almost exclusively man made objects: a windsock, a rope, a plane.

Animating the plane was one of the hardest things I’ve drawn so far. Getting the angle right, the way it lifts or drops by the wind and foreshortening the wing span in perspective; just to name a few hurdles. At one point I almost bought a scale model of a glider so I could see with my own eyes how the form behaves.*

Keeping control of the form took so much time and effort that I decided to deprioritize that and focus on the movement and overall timing instead.

The rope pulling the plane was also trickier than I thought. It turned out I was incapable of drawing the exact same curves over and over again, resulting in a juttery line, so I opted for the vector tool in Opentoonz. That way I could draw a curve, duplicate and edit it in the consecutive frames.

The little bird in the background - the only animate organism - is a nine frame loop. I followed the bird flight guide in Whitaker and Halas' book Timing for Animation. Here it is isolated:

Adding colour to a dark world

All the backgrounds are results of a long process of tuning the composition, grading the colours and layering of various elements. I was partially inspired by a beautiful short animation called L’Ondée, so in the beginning everything was grayscale. Eventually I saw that colours were needed in my particular case to make it more dreamlike and give it more depth, since the gray made it look a little too flat sometimes:

Searching for song

In the final stages I was looking for a melody to accompany the images. Then I remembered Saint-Saëns' Aquarium, alluding to the aforementioned observation of the gliders in the sky. It took some tweaking and shifting of the animations and cuts to follow the rythm and development within the music, but it worked out quite okay. The windvane even seems to mimic the scales in the introduction.

I can’t deny this choice of music invoked a little nod towards Days of Heaven.

All sound effects and recordings used are licensed under creative commons.

item.title: River bank Impression
item.description:
Another impression, this time of a river bank…

… following the same style as the last two.

item.title: Two Moor Impressions
item.description:
I went on a long walk through forests and across moors…

… and made some sketches and photos while I was there, adhering to my new year’s resolution to draw more from life and in the world. I decided to expand on two of them by experimenting with watercolor and a layer of black pilot pen and calligraphy brush on top.

item.title: A New Year's Blessing
item.description:
My blessing for the year ahead.

This is a variation on something I made earlier as a congratulating gift. There was a message written in the sand which I decided not to disclose because only specific people would understand who’s it for and what it’s about. Since 2022 is approaching I took the opportunity to change it into something to end the year with.

The backgrounds are a combination of charcoal drawings and watercolor paintings layered on top of each other.

This is the second time I animated a human being. I knew I wanted a younger person. I tried showing his ‘beach existence’ through his gait and how he carries his body overall; a bit more relaxed and balanced in the joints and wearing loose clothing. I also wanted to make him a bit of an enigma by not showing his face and letting him fade away as he walks out of the frame, as if he’s effected by the same forces that erase the message in the sand.

Animating a wave as in the second shot I tried distilling it to two basic elements: the mass of water and the foam layer on top. Both tend to move at the same speed when the wave comes crashing in, but the foam layer eases in later and expands when the body of water retreats back to the ocean. As a final touch I animated an overlay layer to suggest the wet sand drying after the wave had gone back. I’m guessing animating water is all about keeping it simple.

A nice discovery was the particle generator in Opentoonz. I was able to ‘generate’ the waves in the background of the first shot by drawing a single eddy and letting the generator scatter multiple along the horizon. Fiddling with the parameters long enough resulted in the effect of waves in the distance.

All sounds are gathered gratefully from freesound.org

Wishing you all a healthy and prosperous new year.

item.title: Calligraphy Gestures
item.description: A couple of poses made with watercolor and a Japanese calligraphy pen.

item.title: Ultra Short: Sapling's Fall
item.description:
This started out as a simple experiment of a tree bending in the wind, but I realized I could create a tiny story around it.

Drawing the tree

Animating big slow moving objects takes a very long time and a lot of drawings. I was drawing the tree by hand on paper - and with more detail - so I was very conscious of this and explored various ways on how to mitigate the possibility of being driven absolutely nuts.

When I looked into how The Man Who Planted Trees was made, I noticed they used a double exposure, meaning they shot two drawings in two exposures on a single film frame, so as to ‘fade’ between the drawings to making the transitions less jarring, but this also meant that they didn’t have to draw the inbetween, saving them lots of time on an already massive project.

The tree in this short only consists of 8 drawings. I timed them on 4’s and duplicated the column, shifted it two frames and added a transparency effect to recreate the digital version of the aforementioned double exposure technique.

Animating the sapling

After drawing the tree I decided to expand the animation by adding a character with a follow-up shot. Even though I enjoy animating on paper, I did want to fasten the pace a bit so I decided to animate the character digitally in Krita. It really helps with plotting down a rough animation and editing it on the go.

I mostly held on to the squash and stretch principle for this one, since it’s a creature without any bone structure. Animating the little stick and fig leaf were especially fun; I tried making them pop like pimples.

Drawing and colouring the forest floor

I’m a big fan of Amanita Design’s games. I particularly like their intricate backgrounds which are basically pencil drawings painted and textured in the computer, so I took this opportunity to apply the same technique.

After drawing the linework on paper it was then painted in the computer with a handful of scanned watercolour textures I made earlier. Tweaking the blending modes of the layers and applying lots of layer masks until I was satisfied enough.

Compositing it all together

Opentoonz keeps proving to be a solid open source compositing application for 2D animation. I definitely understand why Studio Ghibli uses it. I enjoy the traditional elements like vertical columns together with ‘modern’ inventions like a node based compositing system.

In this case, to create a sense of depth in the second shot, I added two foreground drawings which are then positioned closer to the camera on the Z-axis, as if to create a little diorama.

Closing thoughts

To conclude I’d like to credit Nicolas Drweski for his triangle sound pack. Almost all of the sounds in this short animation originate from it.

Again I hope this may help someone. By using open source tools freely I feel obliged to at least contribute by explaining how I use them.

item.title: Returning to gesture
item.description:
Lately I’ve been studying Walt Stanchfield’s Drawn to Life. Stanchfield is a really inspiring human being with plenty of wisdom and pragmatism when it comes to getting at the root of animation and drawing. What he keeps emphasizing is the need for clear gesture to get the story across. It is essential in any form of animation. Through the pages I could hear Walt’s voice in my mind, urging me to keep practicing my life drawing.

Below a selection of the gesture- and figure drawings I’ve made during the last few weeks. I’m now slowly trying to find a balance in experimenting with different forms of animation, while at the same time maintaining a steady practice in the essentials.

item.title: Blizzard children
item.description:
Grabbing materials at hand to construct a world.

I have been watching some of Koji Yamamura’s work lately and I’ve been struck by his style. When I was reading a piece on him, something he said caught my eye:

“Digital art is becoming standard worldwide. But if everyone uses the same apps, there’ll be more works with a similar kind of feel. The key is to skilfully combine digital technology with existing techniques. If you’re satisfied with just one easy-to-use digital tool, you can end up closing down possibilities instead of opening them up.”

This really encouraged me to search further in trying out different materials when making animations.

For this particular animation I grabbed a piece of packing paper I had lying around and started to draw on it:

I like that you can still see the creases in the paper, while at the same time being on a hill side.

The snowflakes are made by splashing black watercolour paint on 30 sheets of paper, Jackson Pollock style. I grouped them together based on the different shapes and sizes of the snowflakes, so when sequenced together, it wouldn’t be totally random. There are three layers for the snow, composited interchangeably over each other to forgo any obvious looping.

After scanning I inverted the colors so that the black splatters became white snowflakes.

The group of boys were discovered by coincidence. I knew I wanted a lantern in there and it was only after I had drawn a simple silhouet behind it that I saw the group coming together.

I animated both the lantern and the boys digitally in Krita. The boy layers have an overlay blend mode which causes them to become more like stains in the packing paper. All was then composited together in Opentoonz.

To enhance the atmosphere I added some sound this time.

item.title: Submerged
item.description:
Another Day for Night test; this time a bit more elaborate.

Recently while taking a walk I discovered a stream in the local forest. It was covered with duckweed, flowing downstream and the stream bed looked bottomless. Naturally I dipped my hand in the cool water. The experience fueled the idea for this animation.

All was animated traditionally on paper and composited in Opentoonz.

The hand is based on my own, but I tried to make it a bit more animal-like while underwater.

The duckweeds are painstakingly drawn in around 60 frames and animated on two’s. I painted all the circles with pink watercolor. That took quite a while. Then I composited multiple instances of the same animation to suggest an unending flow.

Here is, again, the ‘uninverted’, original video:

The inversion technique still intrigues me, but I must confess it’s not always the most logical or efficient. Especially since it’s so confusing for the brain while working on it, and trying to imagine the inverted colours. But I think it definitely shines when applied on watercolor layers, which are hard to darken otherwise.

item.title: Day for Night
item.description:
Testing a Day for Night technique by drawing on paper with opposite colors and inverting it back in post.

A technique once commonly used during the previous century, whereby a scene was shot during the day, but made to look -with the help of various filters and lenses- as if it happens at night. Nowadays it is not so common anymore, but I did wonder whether it could be applied to traditional animation where the coloring is done directly on paper.

I figured I wanted to make a night scene with cars' head- and tail lights passing through the frame, so I picked the inverted colors of yellow and red and used blue and teal pencils respectively. The background is also done with inversion in mind, by drawing only the light parts, in this case the moon and tree tops.

Here is the ‘uninverted’, original video:

One could question the relevance of this technique nowadays, even in animation. This is obviously a non-issue in digital animation, and perhaps also in traditional cel animation, where the coloring is done after scanning. Only in ‘niche’ animation could this still be applicable. I do believe it provides for a unique atmosphere and perhaps also something to explore more.

item.title: Resting in the Mud
item.description:
Another attempt at ‘mixed media’ animation, combining analog charcoal drawings with digitally animated characters.

There is one shot in the film A Hidden Life (2019) that keeps popping up in my mind. What fascinates me about it is an animal many times larger optically than the human in the same composition, due to the wide-angle lenses used by cinematographer Jörg Widmer. The shot doesn’t even last more than two seconds, but it does leave a lasting impression (as does the whole movie by the way).

I decided to create an animation based on this style of composition. The characters and scenery were adopted, but the animation itself is not based on the actual movement in the film.

The fore- and background I made as seperate charcoal drawings, to be later composited behind and in front of the characters.

The characters I then animated and colored on seperate layers in Krita:

This is the first time I tried a 4K workflow. There are some quirks to this, but an upside is the ability to crop a certain part of the frame while retaining full HD quality. For example, here is a cropped animation of the woman in the background:

item.title: The Values of Sky
item.description:
Two more charcoal studies of the local sky.

There are most always clouds morphing into all kinds of shapes outside my window. Now that autumn is slowly starting, the tones and volume start to become more textured and layered. I thought it would be nice to try and render these differing shapes and streams in the sky.

The foreground silhouettes of the buildings and roofs are made beforehand by taping them off and rigourously filling them with charcoal. After I applied some fixative, the tape gets removed and sharp edges remain.

The paper is 125 g/m medium grain.

item.title: The Values of Landscape
item.description:
Four landscape studies using charcoal to capture value and tone.

Brushes, erasers and tissues were utilized to blur edges and apply highlights in certain areas. Still messing around with the order in which to apply the various layers of charcoal. It behaves very much like watercolour, where unpredictable things can happen.

I used reference photos for all of them; the first two (landscape) are based on pictures from John Sexton. The last two (portrait) are based on pictures from my iPhone.

For the paper I grabbed 125 g/m medium grain.

item.title: The Zen of Ice Skating
item.description:
I went back to (mostly) analogue animating for this one. The character is drawn with a calligraphy pen and the background cycle is made of charcoal drawings. All was composited in Opentoonz and digitally colored in Krita.

The ice is a series of five charcoal drawings looping on two layers and blended together:

Here is a little video showing the various phases in the workflow:

item.title: Combining 2D with 3D in Blender
item.description:
I was curious to see if it would be possible to create a sense of depth with 2D animation, a medium in which the third dimension seemingly lacks. Something like a virtual diorama where flat elements are positioned deliberately to give an illusion of depth.

To start of I grabbed a character I had drawn earlier:

Animation: from rough to inked and painted.

Compositing in Blender

The colored animation was exported from Krita and imported as an animated ‘Images as Planes’. This makes it possible to move a flat plane containing the animation with an alpha channel. I layed out a grid and added some volumetric lighting, which causes a fog like effect in the distance.

To accentuate the third dimension a light source is positioned diagonally behind the character, which causes skewed shadows. I also animated a spotlight following the movement of the glowing eyes and demonstrates a movement towards- and away from the camera.

The hard part was positioning the different elements within the scene to achieve a correct perspective. I didn’t use any reference or vanishing points when animating the character, so I got there through trial and error. I also couldn’t get the shadow cast by the light source to align properly with the character; if you look closely you can see the shadow not reaching all the way to the base of the feet.

I am aware of Blender’s Grease pencil functionalities, but find those to be still too limited artistically. Therefore I opted to explore this workflow which allows for the best of both worlds.

item.title: Secondary Action
item.description:
An exercise in secondary action and weight. I also wanted to test a digital cel animation workflow with added shadows.

I started out with simple balls where the main body guides the rest:

I animated on two’s in the beginning, but the timing didn’t quite match the weight of the character, so I switched to ones; leaving me with more work, but a better result in the end I think.

While making the rough animation there wasn’t any thought out character yet. I thought of flipped buckets and vegetables, but ultimately settled on a rabit like doll carrying something under its skin:

The secondary action principle also applied to the ears, arms and buttoned eye. I wanted the ears to have a stiffness at the base, so I tried to limit the amount of waviness there. The arms serve as a counter weight to the belly and I left them dangling under its head.

The inking was done in Krita. Same goes for the rough animation. I used pure red lines for the shadows which enabled me to fill those with the designated shadow color in the last stage.

As for the coloring I wanted to utilize Opentoonz, but failed because I was still struggling with its bucket tool. It seems to be too strict when finding edges. Have to do some more research on that. I stayed and colored in Krita instead.

Getting rid of the red shadow lines proved to be difficult as well. The lines were anti-aliased, which confused the paint bucket tool by not fully filling them up, leaving red spots all over the edges of the color planes. The only tool that helped was the ‘Similar Color Selection Tool’, which selected only the red color so I could paint over it.

Learned a lot again with this one! The hardest thing was keeping volume. In hindsight there are some notable volume shifts in the belly and the head towards the end. I’m going to keep an eye out for that.

item.title: Speed sketching on a Pen Display
item.description:
Recently I acquired a pen display to draw and animate with. I decided to record my timed pose studies to gain an objective view of the way I draw. This is a compilation of the sketches I did of poses ranging between 1-, 2- and 4 minutes.

Krita is the software in which I drew. I’m experimenting with different brushes, pencils and pens between the time ranges. I used OBS Studio to record both the pen display and the secondary screen, on which I used a timed slideshow of models from Proko. Not quite like drawing from a real life model, but it’s as close as I can get!

The music is by Plaid (“Tokyo Drive”).

See the gallery below for all the sketches created in this video.

item.title: 11 Second Club: July entry
item.description:
My entry for the 11 Second Club july edition. It is the first time I’m entering this competition and also my first time animating a more rounded (human) character.

I was a bit late to the game, so unfortunately I couldn’t finish the facial animation.

The audio to animate to this month was taken from Atonement (2007). The hard part was coming up with the overall idea; the character in the film recites a letter he wrote, making it unclear where we are diegetically from our point of view. We could be in the same room as him, or in his mind.

Because of this ambiguity I opted for poetic realism. I thought of a soldier in despair of war, seemingly giving up and returning to his memories of promise and joy. There are two contrasting backgrounds; a bleak and dark warzone/beach and a peaceful park.

I tried making the character equally contrasting as well by behaving distinctively in the seperate moments of his life: wading indifferently in the water towards his demise, and ‘swaggering on the promise of life’ towards possibility. The first part is animated on 3’s and the second part on 2’s to underline this.

Here is the animation isolated from the final composite:

I might add facial animation later on, but all in all I’m quite happy with it and excited to see the other entries.

item.title: The Animation Workshop: Personal Scene
item.description:
During a summer school at The Animation Workshop we had to make our own scene based on a simple prompt: “What was that?” All staging, thumbnailing, animating and background creation was done in TVPaint.

Really enjoyed making this piece.

item.title: The Animation Workshop: Animation Exercises
item.description:
I visited the animation summer school at The Animation Workshop in Viborg, Denmark this year. We got to learn a lot about the fundamentals and principles of animating and drawing. This was also my first (proper) introduction to using TVPaint and a Wacom tablet to animate digitally.

Here are some of the exercises I made to get a grasp on weight, volume, timing, spacing etcetera.

Bouncing ball on the spot

Bouncing ball forward

Cannon ball

Bouncing ball with tail

Waving hair

Morphing and looping

For the personal scene I made during the course, please see the dedicated blog post.

item.title: The Animation Workshop: Gesture & Croquis
item.description:
During the animation summer school at The Animation Workshop I attended gesture and croquis classes. They both ranged between 1 minute, 2 minutes and 4 minutes per pose.

Gesture drawing

Croquis

item.title: Three colored poses
item.description: Three scribbly poses made with bold marker and colored pencils.

item.title: Struggling with Feet - part 1
item.description: Trying to tackle the drawing of feet. 3B pencil on paper.

item.title: Lifting a rock (in pastel)
item.description:
A return to the basic animation principles: a character lifting something heavy. I wanted an element of slapstick in the scene, hence the hat.

The material I used is black pastel which I wanted to try out for animation. However the regret eventually came when it proved to create double the amount of work. It wasn’t suited for this kind of animation. In the end I opted for a chalky look by using the invertion trick.

item.title: Calligraphy poses
item.description:
An attempt at using a calligraphy brush and watercolour paint to capture the human form. I applied the brush on A3 sized smooth watercolouring paper. The poses were between 2-3 minutes.

The colours are inverted for clarity (but also because the amber looks really cool). See below for the originals in blue.

item.title: Stuck in the mud
item.description:
Technically a walkcycle, but the character takes quite a few frames to even take one step. I wanted to get to a sense of the forces that occur when a character wants to move forward, but is held back by external circumstances. He could be stuck in mud or something else that’s sticky.

I didn’t use much reference this time, but I did look at this short piece in Spirited Away:

It shows how to animate when there is resistance; a foot getting freed and moving fast and sudden because of the force that’s being applied.

The decision for using a style marker was totally random. I was just curious how it would look animated. The marker was already at its last ink, so that’s why the the drawings get thinner and more abstracted once it reaches the end.

item.title: Frogs and Cycles (of Life)
item.description:
This proved to be a study in efficiency: when to cycle and repeat through certain frames in order to extend the animation.

It was necessity since the entire scene was too long to fully plan ahead. I had a vague notion of how everything could interact once it would all come together, so I animated each object or character on its own and later on retimed the sequences where there was room for repetition - such as the croaking of the frog and the bending of the reeds.

I wanted the waves to come from very far and for the viewer to notice them long before the frog has any clue. This meant that a wave had to take 220 frames to reach the shore. I decided to animate them on 3’s and duplicate a single wave three times, to prevent myself from suffering too much. By slowly increasing its spacing on this perpective grid, a sense of distance is achieved:

The frog was very small on paper (5mm) so I had to keep its shape simple. I looked at the frogs in this amazing sequence of The Tale of the Princess Kaguya:

Upon closer inspection I noticed they animated them on 2’s. One leap takes only 4 sheets of paper. Even though the movement is fast, animating them on ones isn’t necessary at all. This again shows that spacing each frame correctly is far more effective than just drawing as many frames as one can.

I’ll leave the frogs for now.

item.title: Cel animation and frogs
item.description:
In this exercise I wanted to try the (digital) cel animation technique.

First I began with the background:

I thought what could take place in this kind of environment, so obviously a frog running from lightning seemed logical.

The animation can be better, but the original intention of this exercise was getting a feel for the cel animation workflow.

After this first pass I traced a new layer on paper with all the lines intersecting each other. Opentoonz' supplementary scan tool ‘GTS’ has a trace feature which automatically recognizes the lines and converts them to rasterized lines, which makes filling in the colors a lot easier.

The paint bucket tool was used to fill in all the ‘cells’:

In the end I opted for black and white, since the colors didn’t blend too well with the rest of the scene. I will also try adding shadow cells next time.

Opentoonz has a helpful node system which I used for final compositing - matting out certain pieces and adding little effects such as noise and inverting the lightning.

Thanks for reading. Hope this may help someone!

item.title: Pose Studies
item.description: Pose drawings varying between 2 and 5 minutes. Conté and watercolour on paper.

item.title: Throwing a Boomerang
item.description:
This time I tried my hand at motion blurring, overlapping action, cutting to a new shot and compositing on backgrounds.

For inspiration I looked at Ohira Shinya’s work.

For preparation I studied a world champion boomerang thrower:

The first pass of animation contains a handful of extremes to determine the timing:

Final pass:

For animating the boomerang I turned to the perspective principle from Richard Williams' book.

After I made the final pass I thought of leaving it as is, but decided to give it a bit more depth. I considered coloring the character with charcoal on paper, however I was hesitant of the mess it would give so I painted digitally using Krita:

The backgrounds I did make with charcoal:

Opentoonz was used to composite all the layers together and lift the camera:

item.title: Watercolour Weekend
item.description: Some watercolour sketches of mental imagery made during the weekend.

item.title: Struggling with Hands - part 2
item.description: More studies of my left hand in various poses. Also tried drawing with a Wacom (last 2).

item.title: Struggling with Hands - part 1
item.description: Trying to tackle the rendering of hands by studying and drawing my own left hand.

item.title: Struggling with Heads - part 3
item.description: Structuring the head in simple planes to get a better sense of how it manifests itself in 3D space. The more complicated the planes the closer it comes to an actual human face, like adding more polygons to a 3D-model.

item.title: Struggling with Heads - part 2
item.description: Diving into the basic bone structure of the head and figuring out how everything fits. Heads are weird.

item.title: Struggling with Heads - part 1
item.description: My first foray into understanding and drawing basic heads. To be continued…

item.title: Even more figure drawing Stickybones
item.description: More figure drawings of a Stickybones mannequin in various poses and angles. Originally blue pencil on white paper, but inverted to examine linework.

item.title: Figure drawing Stickybones
item.description: Figure drawings of a Stickybones mannequin in various poses and angles.

item.title: Weight & Hard Accent
item.description: Trying to give weight (or no weight) to a feather and also an attempt at animating anticipations and ‘hard accents’: the arm anticipates and moves abruptly to catch the feather.

item.title: Walkcycle in Perspective
item.description:
An exercise in animating a walkcycle on the third Z-dimension. Though animated on 3’s, it’s interesting to see that the further away the character gets, the less the animation seems to be ‘limited’ or jaggy because of the increased overlap in the spacing between the individual frames. I suppose one could get away with animating characters or objects in the distance on 3’s.

I used the technique from Richard Williams' book on where to place the key positions:

item.title: 2 Minute Poses with pen
item.description: Figure drawings of 2 minute poses with pen on paper. The shading is added in a later stage with conté.

item.title: 5 Minute Poses
item.description: Figure drawings of 5 minute poses made with conté on paper. Trying to add more mass and shading this time.

item.title: More pose studies
item.description:
Figure drawings of 1 minute poses. Conté on paper.

‘Robo Bean’ studies of twisting torso’s:

item.title: 16 frame walk + overlapping action
item.description:
In this animation I tried to combine multiple exercises:

  • 2 subjects reacting to each other
  • A 16-frame “leisurely” walkcycle on 2’s and bringing it to a halt
  • Animating overlapping action; in this case, the opened box lids drag behind its core movement. Also, the head of the figure extends slightly more after its back has arched backwards.
  • Small expression animations, which added up to a total of 4 animation layers.

Initial layout:

item.title: Headturn
item.description:
My first attempt at a headturn. Animated on 2’s.

Initial layout:

item.title: 8 Frame Runcycle on 1's
item.description:
A runcycle where one step spans 8 frames. The arm swing is kept to a minimum to prevent too much action happening in a short amount of time.

Here it is on 2’s:

Initial layout:

item.title: Breaking joints
item.description:
An exercise in ‘breaking joints’ where the elbows twist and turn in a way only possible in animation.

Also added a secondary animation layer; in this case the eyes.

item.title: Timed pose studies
item.description:
1 Minute poses:

30 Second poses:

45 Second poses:

Abstracting torso’s with two bean shapes in perspective:

Scribbly poses where the pencil stays on the paper, 30 seconds:

item.title: 8 Frame Walkcycle on 2's
item.description: Study of an 8 frame walkcycle on 2’s where the torso and head stay leveled.

item.title: 12 Frame Walkcycle on 3's
item.description: Study of a bouncy 12 frame walkcycle on 3’s. No inbetweens.

item.title: Ball in perspective
Falling flour sack
item.description: Study of a sack of flour falling to the ground. Traditionally animated on 2’s.

item.title: 12 Frame Walkcycle on 1's
Matryoshka Balls
Various Watercolor sketches
item.description: Various watercolor sketches and studies.
